bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Domingo F. Ramos, December 6, 1944

div1.p: Hench inquires about the preparations for the meeting in Cuba. He would like to attend and offers to loan his slides on yellow fever to Ramos.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Domingo F. Ramos, December 6, 1944
div1.opener:
PSH/cb
6 December, 1944
Doctor Domingo Ramos
Director, Finlay Institute
Habana, Cuba
My dear Doctor Ramos:
div1.p:
I do not wish to bother you unduly, but I wondered if you
received the collection of photographs which I sent to you. Have your
plans for a Spring meeting in Cuba materialized any further? The reason
I ask is that I have had invitations to speak at two meetings, one at
the end of January and one at the end of February, and if there is any
prospect of the Cuban meeting occurring, I do not want to accept any in-
vitations that might conflict. May I ask you frankly whether you thought
that General Kirk's interest in your suggestion regarding me was merely a
polite interest, or do you believe that he was really in earnest about the
matter?

I have been asked to give my illustrated lecture on Yellow
Fever toward the latter part of January. Should you wish to borrow any
of my slides, will this date conflict with your wishes in the matter? I
am going home in a fewtwo weeks and would appreciate greatly knowing whether
you want any of these slides. It is possible that if you only wanted a
few, I could ask the Clinic to make these few for you to keep, rather than
to borrow.

closer.signed:
PHILIP S. HENCH, Lt. Col., M.C.
Chief of the Medical Service
